contextId.information: Here evil is spoken of as if it were a place that a person could avoid going to, instead of the doing of evil actions. AT: "refused to do evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turned from evil

contextId.information: Just as a barrier such as a wall or a hedge surrounds and protects one's land, God has surrounded Job with his protection. AT: "protected him and his house and all that is his" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: put a barrier around him, around his house, and around all that is his from every side

contextId.information: Here "mouth" represents the part of swords that kill people, that is, either the point or the sharp edge. Also, all the swords of the men from Sheba are spoken of as if they were only one sword. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_genericnoun]])
contextId.quote: the mouth of the sword

contextId.information: This refers to a time when God is paying attention. AT: "in your hearing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to your face

contextId.information: A woman's womb is spoken of as if it were a container with doors. AT: "because that day did not close my mother's womb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: because it did not shut up the doors of my mother's womb

contextId.information: Here Job speaks of his future, which he does not know in advance, as if God had hidden it from him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whose way is hidden

contextId.information: Here becoming discouraged is spoken of as if it were falling down. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: falling

contextId.information: Here trouble is spoken of as if it were an object that could come to a person. AT: "But now you suffer from disasters" See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But now trouble has come to you

contextId.information: Here the actions of plowing and sowing represent causing trouble for other people. The action of reaping represents suffering the trouble that one has himself caused. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: plow iniquity ... sow trouble ... reap

contextId.information: This may represent the action of God giving a command. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the breath of God

contextId.information: The second builds on the first. They make the same point by using meanings that increase the result. "By the puff of God's mouth they die; the rushing wind of his anger devastates them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: breath ... blast

contextId.information: Here a person is spoken of as if he were a plant, perhaps becoming more foolish over time. AT: "a foolish person becoming grounded in foolishness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a foolish person taking root

contextId.information: Here greedy people are spoken of as if they were thirsty, and the wealth of the foolish person is spoken of as if it were something that they could drink. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The thirsty pant for their wealth

contextId.information: This refers to things that mankind cannot understand.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unsearchable things

contextId.information: Humble people in distress are spoken of as if they were in a low position. When God rescues them, they receive honor. When this happens, they are spoken of as being raised up and put into a high position. AT: "God does this in order to rescue and honor the humble who have been suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He does this in order to set up on high those who are low

contextId.information: Here making wise people suffer for their own evil actions is spoken of as if it were catching them in traps. Their own actions are spoken of as if they were those traps. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He traps wise people in their own crafty actions

contextId.information: Here the cunning, wicked people whom God confuses are spoken of as if they unexpectedly are in the dark at noon, when the sun is at its highest position in the sky. They cannot do anything they wish to do, because they cannot see. AT: "Those who are cunning are in the dark, even at noontime" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They encounter darkness in the daytime

contextId.information: Here the insulting and threatening things that people say are spoken of as if they were a sword in their mouths. AT: "But he saves the poor person from the threats of the mighty" or "But he saves the poor person when the mighty threaten or insult them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But he saves the poor person from the sword in their mouths

contextId.information: Here "tent" represents a person's family, household, and all his possessions. AT: "You will know that your family, servants, and everything you own are safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You will know that your tent is in safety

contextId.information: Here "seed" represents a person's descendants. AT: "your descendants will be many"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your seed will be great

contextId.information: Job compares the burden of his suffering to the weight of wet sand; both can crush a person. "For they would be heavier than the sand on the seashore" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas

contextId.information: This speaks of a person who feels hopeless and is overwhelmed by his troubles as if he were about to physically faint. AT: "who feels hopeless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who is about to faint

contextId.information: The worms and clods of dust are pictured as covering Job as if they were clothing. AT: "My flesh is covered with worms and clods of dust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust

contextId.information: Job compares the shortness of his life to the shortness of a breath. AT: "my life is very short, like taking one breath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my life is only a breath

contextId.information: Job compares his troubles from God to the effects of a tempest. AT: "He injures me as if with a tempest." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For he breaks me with a tempest

contextId.information: Here "you hid in your heart" means God kept them secret or hidden. AT: "these things you kept secret" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: these things you hid in your heart

contextId.information: God sending troubles against Job is spoken of as if God was constantly sending new armies against him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you attack me with fresh armies

contextId.information: Here being brought out of the womb represents being born into this world. AT: "brought me out of my mother's womb" or "brought me into this world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: brought me out of the womb

contextId.information: God's greatness or wisdom is spoken of as if it could be measured in distance. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is longer than the earth ... wider than the sea

contextId.information: The heart represents thoughts and attitudes. Setting it right represents correcting it. AT: "even if you had corrected your attitude" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: suppose that you had set your heart right

contextId.information: Brightness represents being prosperous and happy. AT: "Your life would be prosperous and happy like the noonday" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your life would be brighter than the noonday

contextId.information: Possible meanings are that withholding waters represents 1) preventing the rain from falling. AT: "if he stops the rain from falling the land dries up" or 2) preventing running water from flowing. AT: "if he stops the water from flowing, the land dries up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if he withholds the waters, they dry up

contextId.information: Leading counselors away barefoot represents taking away their wisdom and authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He leads counselors away barefoot

contextId.information: Leading priests away barefoot represents taking away their authority. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He leads priests away barefoot in sorrow

contextId.information: Pouring contempt on princes is a metaphor for causing people to feel contempt about them. AT: "He causes people to greatly disrespect those who rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He pours contempt upon princes

contextId.information: Revealing things represents either making them known. "Deep things from darkness" represent secrets that people do not know. AT: "He makes known secrets that people do not know"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He reveals deep things from darkness

contextId.information: Taking away their understanding represents causing them to be unable to understand. AT: "He causes the leaders of the people of the earth to be unable to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He takes away understanding from the leaders of the people of the earth

contextId.information: Being in the dark without light represents lacking knowledge. AT: "They struggle to make decisions without knowledge as people struggle to walk in the dark without light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They grope in the dark without light

contextId.information: Putting whitewash or plaster on the truth represents ignoring the truth. AT: "you hide the truth with lies" or "you lie and ignore the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you whitewash the truth with lies

contextId.information: Ashes represent things that are worthless and do not last. AT: "Your memorable sayings are worthless like ashes" or "Your memorable sayings will be forgotten like ashes that are blown away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Your memorable sayings are proverbs made of ashes

contextId.information: Setting his defense in order represents deciding what he will say to defend himself. AT: "I have thought through how I will defend myself" or "I have decided how I will explain myself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have set my defense in order

contextId.information: "Leaf" and "stubble" are metaphors describing Job's weakness, insignifance and fraility. AT: "You persecute me, but I am weak like a leaf blown by the wind and insignificant like dry stubble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: driven leaf ... dry stubble

contextId.information: "Bitter things" represents accusations. AT: "You write down accusations against me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you write down bitter things against me

contextId.information: Doing this represents punishing Job and keeping him from living freely as if Job had committed a crime and was a prisoner. AT: "It is as though you put my feet in the stocks" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You also put my feet in the stocks

contextId.information: Examining this ground represents examining all that Job has done. AT: "It is as though you examine the ground where I have walked" or "You examine everything I do like a person examining someone's footsteps on the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you examine the ground where the soles of my feet have walked

contextId.information: Disappearing represents dying. AT: "so that its young shoot will not die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that its tender stalk does not disappear

contextId.information: Sealing transgression in a bag represents hiding it and refusing to think about it. This can be stated in active form. AT: "You would refuse to think about my transgression like someone who hides something in a bag" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My transgression would be sealed up in a bag

contextId.information: Something that God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if it were physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: clean

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked man acting aggressively against God as if he were running towards him to attack him. AT: "attacks God" or "acts violently against God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: runs at God

contextId.information: Here the flame represents God's judgment and the drying up of his stalks represents either the fact that his possessions disappear, or that he will die. AT: "God will take everything he owns away, like a fire dries out the moist branches of a tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a flame will dry up his stalks

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked man growing weak and dying as if he were a grapevine dropping unripe grapes. AT: "Just like a grapevine drops its unripe grapes, so the wicked man will drop his strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will drop his unripe grapes like a grapevine

contextId.information: Job speaks of thinking of useless things to say as if his words were random items that he collected and joined together. AT: "I could think of things to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I could collect and join words together

contextId.information: This speaks of God causing Job pain as if he were a wild animal and Job were his prey that he was killing. AT: "Because God is very angry with me, it is as though he were a wild animal that tore my body apart with his teeth because he was my enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has torn me in his wrath and persecuted me ... as he tears me apart

contextId.information: Job speaks of his pain and despair as if he himself were something that was broken into pieces. AT: "but then it felt as though he broke me apart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and he broke me apart

contextId.information: Job speaks of himself being the focus of God's attacks as if God has set him up as a target and God had arches surrounding him to attach him. AT: "It is as though his archers have me surrounded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His archers surround me all around

contextId.information: Job speaks of wearing clothing made of sackcloth as if the cloth was attached to his body. People often wore sackcloth to express mourning or great grief. AT: "Because I am mourning, I have sewn together sackcloth to wear as my clothing" or "I wear clothing that I made from sackcloth, because I am mourning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have sewn sackcloth on my skin

contextId.information: Job begins to speak to God. Here he speaks of his situation as if he were in prison. He is asking God to provide a pledge so that he may be released. AT: "God, give now a pledge so that I may be released from this prison" or "pay for my release from prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Give now a pledge, be a guarantee for me with yourself

contextId.information: This speaks of the people claiming that night is day as if they actually changed night into day. AT: "they claim it is daytime when it is night" or "what they say is the opposite of what is true, just as night is the opposite of day" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: change the night into day

contextId.information: Job speaks of the closeness he will soon have with his grave by comparing it to the closeness a man has with his father. AT: "You are as close to me as my father" or "When I am buried, you will be as close to me as a father" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You are my father

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked person suddenly experiencing disaster as if he no longer had strength  to walk. AT: "It will be like he no long has the strength to walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The steps of his strength will be made short

contextId.information: These four phrases speak of the wicked man experiencing disaster as if he was caught in a trap. AT: "It will be as though a trap will take him ... a snare will ... A noose is ... and a trap for him in the way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A trap will take him ... a snare will ... A noose is ... and a trap for him in the way

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked man becoming poor and hungry as if he wealth was something that turned into somethings else. AT: "Instead of being wealthy, he will become poor and hungry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His wealth will turn into hunger

contextId.information: This speaks of the wicked man dying and having no descendants as if he were a tree whose roots dried up and branches withered, producing no fruit. AT: "He will die and leave no descendants, he will be like a tree whose roots have dried up and whose branches have all withered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His roots will be dried up ... branch be cut off

contextId.information: Job uses these images to say that God has taken his good reputation, wealth, and prosperity away from him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has stripped ... the crown from my head

contextId.information: Being "far from" someone represents being unwilling to relate to him or help him. AT: "God has caused my brothers to stay away from me" or "God caused my brothers to refuse to help me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has put my brothers far from me

contextId.information: Zophar's thoughts making him do something represent his strong desire to do something. AT: "I want very much to answer you quickly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My thoughts make me answer quickly

contextId.information: The wicked man's height represents either his reputation or his pride. AT: "Though his reputation reaches to the heavens" or "Though his pride reaches to the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Though his height reaches up to the heavens

contextId.information: Here "wickedness is sweet" represents a person enjoying doing wicked things. AT: "Although doing wicked things is pleasurable like tasting sweet food in the mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Although wickedness is sweet in his mouth

contextId.information: When food turns bitter in the stomach, it causes pain and a bitter taste. This is a metaphor for a person experiencing the painful consequences of doing wicked things. AT: "those wicked things become like food that has turned bitter in the stomach" or "the consequences of those wicked things are painful like food that becomes sour in the stomach" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the food in his intestines turns bitter

contextId.information: Zophar speaks of gaining and losing wealth as if it were food that a person eats and vomits. AT: "The wicked person becomes very wealthy, but he loses his wealth like a person who vomits up his food. God causes him to lose it all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He swallows down riches ... cast them out of his stomach

contextId.information: Here "suck the poison of asps" represents doing evil things. Both are very dangerous. AT: "Doing evil things is like sucking the poison of asps" or "He will do evil things and endanger his life like a person who sucks the poison of asps" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will suck the poison of asps

contextId.information: The "fierceness of his wrath" represents God's anger and punishment. Throwing the punishment on him represents punishing him severely. AT: "God will be angry and throw down his punishment on him" or "God will be angry and punish him severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God will throw the fierceness of his wrath on him

contextId.information: This represents him suddenly becoming very afraid. AT: "he is terrified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: terrors come on him

contextId.information: "Complete darkness" is a metaphor for destruction.   AT: "Destruction is reserved for his treasures" or "His treasures will be destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Complete darkness is reserved for his treasures

contextId.information: Here "portion from God" represents what God has decided should happen to someone. It is spoken of as if it were something that God would give him. AT: "This is what God has decided should happen to the wicked man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This is the wicked man's portion from God

contextId.information: Job compares extinguishing the lamp to a person dying. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that God causes them to die suddenly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the lamp of wicked people is put out

contextId.information: Guilt is spoken of as something that can be stored for later use. Here "to pay" refers to punishment for sin. AT: "God keeps a record of a person's sins, then he punishes the person's children for his wicked deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God lays up one's guilt for his children to pay

contextId.information: Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and "soul" refers to the whole man. AT: "with anger and resentment" or "after living a sad life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: in bitterness of soul

contextId.information: Eliphaz compares Job's restoration to the rebuilding of a house that has fallen. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he will heal you and make you prosper again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you will be built up

contextId.information: Possible meanings of "light" are 1) visible light or 2) spiritual light, which refers to God or living righteously. AT: "hate the daylight" or "do not want to do things openly" or "they rebel against God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rebel against the light

contextId.information: Here "fringes" represents a small part that we can see of something that is much bigger. AT: "See, these things that God has done show only a small part of his great power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: See, these are but the fringes of his ways

contextId.information: The "thunder of his power" represents the greatness of all that God does. Job uses this question to emphasize that God's power is so great that no one can understand it. AT: "No one can understand the greatness of his power!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Who can understand the thunder of his power?

contextId.information: Justice is spoken of as if it were an object that could be taken away or given. Taking it away represents refusing to treat Job with justice. AT: "has refused to treat me justly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has taken away my justice

contextId.information: Here "hold fast" to is a metaphor that represents being determined to continue to say something. The abstract noun "righteousness" can be expressed with "righteous." AT: "I am determined to continue saying that I am righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: I hold fast to my righteousness

contextId.information: This is a metaphor meaning "kill him" or "cause him to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cuts him off

contextId.information: Here "ties up the streams" represents damming or blocking the streams. AT: "He blocks the streams so they do not flow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He ties up the streams so they do not run

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) wisdom is spoken of as if it were something that people could buy. AT: "People do not know what it is worth" or 2) the word translated as "price" means "place." AT: "People do not know where it is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Man does not know its price

contextId.information: Here "depart from evil" represents refusing to do evil things. The abstract noun "understanding" can be expressed with the verb "understand." AT: "to refuse to do evil things is understanding" or "if you refuse to do evil things, you will be able to understand things well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to depart from evil is understanding

contextId.information: Job speaks of when he was young and strong as if his days were the time when the harvest is ripe. AT: "when I was young and strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the ripeness of my days

contextId.information: People often spoke of righteousness as if it were clothing.  AT: "I did what was righteous, and it was like clothing that I put on" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I put on righteousness, and it clothed me

contextId.information: This represents helping blind people. AT: "I was like eyes for blind people" or "I guided blind people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I was eyes to blind people

contextId.information: Here "I was a father" represents providing for people. AT: "I provided for needy people as a father provides for his children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I was a father to needy people

contextId.information: Job speaks of unrighteous people who persecute others as if they were wild animals that attack their victims by picking them up between their teeth. AT: "I made unrighteous people stop persecuting people, like someone who breaks the jaw of a wild animal and rescues its victim from between its teeth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I broke the jaws of ... I plucked the victim

contextId.information: Here "were the sons of fools" represents having the characteristics fools. AT: "They were like fools" or "they were fools" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They were the sons of fools

contextId.information: The word "indeed" shows that what follows strengthens the previous thought. Here "sons of nameless people" represents having the characteristics of nameless people. AT: "indeed, they were nameless people" or "indeed, they were worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: indeed, sons of nameless people

contextId.information: A bow that is unstrung is not useful. The phrase "has unstrung the string of my bow" is a metaphor for making Job powerless. AT: "God has taken away my power to defend myself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has unstrung the string to my bow

contextId.information: Job speaks as if his life were a liquid and his body were a container. He feels he is about to die. AT: "Now I am dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Now my life is pouring out from within me

contextId.information: Job speaks of the pain in his bones as if is bones were being pierced. AT: "my bones ache terribly" or "I have sharp pain in my bones" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my bones in me are pierced

contextId.information: The image of God's force seizing Job is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) it represents Job's pain. AT: "My pain feels like God has grabbed my clothing tightly" or 2) it represents God's causing Job's many problems. AT: "It is as though by his great force God has grabbed me by my clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God's great force has seized my clothing

contextId.information: Job says that God has humiliated him. AT: "It is as though he has thrown me in the mud" or "He has humiliated me, like a person thrown in the mud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He has thrown me into the mud

contextId.information: These expressions represent the extreme suffering that God made Job endure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lift me up to the wind ... throw me back and forth in a storm

contextId.information: Here "bring me to death" represents causing Job to die. AT: "you will cause me to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will bring me to death

contextId.information: Job speaks of making a promise about what he would look at as though his eyes were a person and he made a covenant with them. AT: "I have made a firm promise about what I will look at" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: I have made a covenant with my eyes

contextId.information: People used balances to weigh items and to determine their value. This image represents judging honestly. It can be stated in active form. AT: "let me be judged honestly" or "let God judge me honestly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: let me be weighed in an even balance

contextId.information: Here "my step" is a metaphor for Job's behavior, and "turned out of the right way" is a metaphor for changing from living right. AT: "If I have changed from living right" or "If I have stopped doing what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If my step has turned out of the right way

contextId.information: Here "my steps" represents Job's actions. AT: "I would declare to him and accounting for all I have done" or "I would tell him everything I have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I would declare to him an accounting for my steps

contextId.information: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "he considered himself righteous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in his own eyes

contextId.information: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. Also, this can be stated in active form. AT: "Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry with Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Then was kindled the anger of Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; it was kindled against Job

contextId.information: This compares Elihu's anger to someone starting a fire. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Elihu also became very angry with his three friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Elihu's anger was also kindled against his three friends

contextId.information: This means that the men were done speaking to Job. This speaks of the men possibly having an answer as if the answer were an object that would be in their mouths. AT: "that these three men had nothing else to say" or "and these three men had no more answers to give Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of having a lot to say as being full of words. AT: "I have so much to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am full of words

contextId.information: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. AT: "I am just as you are in God's judgment" or "God judges you the same way that he judges me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am just as you are in God's sight

contextId.information: This speaks of God making people aware of things as if he were opening their ears so that they could hear. AT: "then God reveals things to people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: then God opens the ears of men

contextId.information: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." AT: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the pit

contextId.information: The place where people go when they die is referred to here as "the pit." AT: "the place where dead people are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the pit

contextId.information: This speaks of saving the man from dying as if he had died and was being brought back to life. AT: "to keep him from dying and going to the pit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to bring his soul back from the pit

contextId.information: These two questions speak of God not punishing wicked people as if he were being silent and hiding his face. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When he stays silent, who can condemn him? ... If he hides his face, who can perceive him?

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of explaining things to Job as if he were going to show those things to Job. AT: "I will explain some things to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will show you some things

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of God protecting righteous people as if God were watching them with his eyes, and of God ceasing to protect them as if he withdrew his eyes from them. AT: "He doe not stop protecting the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He does not withdraw his eyes from righteous people

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of God honoring the righteous people as if he lifted them up to a high place. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he lifts them up" or "he honors them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they are lifted up

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of living prosperously as if it were having one's table filled with the best foods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: where your table would be set with food full of fatness

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of the lightening that storms cause as if God were holding the lightening in his hand and directing it to strike where he wills. Possible meanings are 1) that God holds the lightning bolts in his hands in order to throw them, or 2) that God hides the lightning bolts in his hands until he is ready to use them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He fills his hands with the lightning

contextId.information: Elihu continues to speak of the thunder as if it is God's voice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A voice roars after it ... the voice of his majesty

contextId.information: Elihu speaks of the storm blowing in from the south as if the storm has a place where it resides until it comes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The storm comes from its chamber in the south

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "we cannot approach him" or 2) this is a metaphor in which Elihu speaks of a person's being unable to fully understand God as if he could not find God. AT: "we cannot comprehend him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: we cannot find him

contextId.information: "obscures my plans" or "confuses my purposes." How Job confuses God's plans is spoken of as if he were making God's plans harder to see. The abstract noun "darkness" can be translated as the verb "darkens." AT: "darkens plans" or "makes plans hard to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: brings darkness to plans

contextId.information: Yahweh describes creating the earth as though he was building a structure. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I laid the earth's foundations

contextId.information: Yahweh compares the way that he prevented the sea from covering all of the earth to holding it back with doors. AT: "prevented the water from flooding over the land" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: shut up the sea with doors

contextId.information: The light of dawn is spoken of as if it seizes the horizons of the earth. AT: "grasp the ends of the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: take hold of the sides of the earth

contextId.information: Death is spoken of as if it were a city that had gates through which people enter into it. This can be expressed in active form. AT: "Has anyone shown the gates of death to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Have the gates of death been revealed to you

contextId.information: Snow and hail are pictured as being stored by Yahweh to do his will. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: storehouses for the snow ... storehouses for the hail

contextId.information: The horse runs over the ground so quickly that the ground passes by like water that a person drinks. AT: "runs very fast over the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: swallows up ground

contextId.information: Both shields and Leviathan's hide protect well and keep arrows and other weapons away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: shields

contextId.information: Fire is a metaphor for anger, and starting a fire is a metaphor for becoming angry. AT: "I have become very angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My wrath is kindled against you
